body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.

If you cannot produce a minimal reproduction case (something that would work in
isolation), please provide the steps or even link to a repository that causes
the problematic output to occur.
-->

Given the following code: https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=2c08f9bdc96b83e64fe82f6ec8cd0813

```rust
fn foo(_f: impl Fn()) {}

fn bar<T>(v: T) -> T { v }

fn main() {
    foo(|| { bar(1) });
}
```

The current output is:

```
error[E0308]: mismatched types
 --> src/main.rs:6:18
  |
6 |     foo(|| { bar(1) });
  |              --- ^ expected `()`, found integer
  |              |
  |              arguments to this function are incorrect
  |
note: function defined here
 --> src/main.rs:3:4
  |
3 | fn bar<T>(v: T) -> T { v }
  |    ^^^    ----
```

<!-- The following is not always necessary. -->
Ideally rustc should suggest inserting a semicolon, like [it does if `bar()` isn't generic](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=87f1dfd04fc50a75ff656619eb95d61a).

I understand this is hard because inference flows backward and thus we don't get to understand that `T` is `i32` and there should be a semicolon but we think that `T` is `()` and `v` is of the wrong type. Maybe this is even impossible: feel free to close if this is the case. But if there is something we can do, it may be nice to try.

@rustbot label +A-suggestion-diagnostics
